title: Jason Gardiner says teen pregnancy fell because they’re ‘doing it from behind'
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Jason Gardiner has claimed teenage pregnancy has fallen in the UK because they’re having a crack at anal sex instead.

The 47-year-old former Dancing On Ice judge made the bizarre, and seemingly unfounded, claim on Channel 5’s Jeremy Vine show – prompting some hesitant giggles from the audience.

While discussing the news that government ministers had dropped plans to enforce age verification rules on porn websites, the topic swiftly shifted to the drop in teenage pregnancies in England.

Speaking on the show, Jason said: ‘We have seen a decline in teenage pregnancy, and do you know why? Because they’re doing it from behind.

‘It is having an effect.’

As the audience cackled, host Jeremy Vine took a while to pick up on Jason’s phrasing and movements.

Jason Gardiner on Jeremy Vine (Picture: Channel 5)

‘Alright, alright,’ Jeremy said. ‘I’m so slow.’

As the next guest prepared to speak, Jeremy interjected: ‘Don’t say anything more shocking than that.’

Office for National Statistics data showed teenage pregnancy rates fell from 18.3 to 16.7 conceptions per 1,000 women aged 15 to 17, between April 2019 and June last year in England.

The British Pregnancy Advisory Service (BPAS) didn’t pin the decline on an abundance of anal sex, however, but instead on an awareness of contraception and a change in the lifestyles of young people.

A BPAS spokeswoman, said: ‘Over the last decade we have seen significant declines in levels of binge drinking among young people, and significant increases in the amount of socialising that takes place online rather than in person.

‘Young people report spending a lot of time at home with their family rather than being out with their friends. This is also a generation that is acutely aware of the political and economic environment around them.

‘They are concerned that they may struggle to achieve the same financial stability as their parents’ generation, and are focusing on their education and careers in order to do so.’
